definitions: showing bold daring and flamboyant confidence typical of romantic adventure heroes
examples: The swashbuckling pirate captain led his crew through dangerous waters
Her swashbuckling personality made her perfect for action movies

definitions: extending or moving over a large area in a smooth continuous motion
affecting many things or people with dramatic thoroughness and broad scope
examples: The sweeping view from the mountaintop took their breath away
She made a sweeping gesture with her arm across the horizon
The government announced sweeping changes to healthcare policy
His sweeping statement ignored many important details

definitions: having sugar or another sweet substance added to improve taste
made more appealing or pleasant to make something easier to accept
examples: She preferred sweetened tea with honey instead of sugar
The sweetened cereal was popular with children
The company sweetened the deal with additional benefits
His sweetened offer finally convinced her to accept

definitions: extremely good, excellent, or first-rate in quality or character
examples: They had a swell time at the jazz festival
What a swell idea to meet at the beach

definitions: increased in size, volume, or extent through internal pressure or growth
filled or inflated with a strong emotion such as pride or anger
examples: His swelled ankle needed immediate medical attention
The swelled river threatened to overflow its banks
Her swelled pride was evident in her confident posture
His swelled ego made him difficult to work with

definitions: cleaned or cleared by brushing away dirt or debris with a broom
arranged or styled in a smooth flowing manner suggesting continuous movement
examples: The swept floor gleamed in the morning sunlight
She kept the swept porch free of autumn leaves
Her swept hairstyle complemented her elegant evening gown
The swept design of the building suggested forward motion

definitions: moving or capable of moving with great speed or velocity
happening quickly or promptly without delay in time or action
examples: The swift current carried the boat downstream rapidly
A swift runner won the marathon by several minutes
The company took swift action to address customer complaints
Justice was swift in the small claims court

definitions: relating to or used for the activity of moving through water
appearing to move in a wavy, blurred, or dizzy manner
examples: She bought new swimming goggles for her morning laps
The swimming instructor taught advanced diving techniques
His swimming vision made it hard to read
The swimming sensation in her head signaled a migraine

definitions: moving rhythmically backward and forward or from side to side while suspended
characterized by lively, exciting, and fashionable activity or atmosphere
examples: The swinging pendulum marked each passing second precisely
Children love the swinging seats at the playground
The swinging nightclub scene attracted young professionals downtown
They enjoyed the swinging music of the jazz era

definitions: impressively smart, elegant, or fashionable in appearance or style
examples: The swish restaurant required formal attire for dinner
Her swish apartment overlooked the city's financial district

definitions: enlarged beyond normal size due to fluid accumulation or inflammation
inflated with excessive pride, arrogance, or self-importance
examples: The swollen river flooded several neighborhoods after heavy rain
Her swollen fingers made it difficult to remove rings
His swollen ego prevented him from accepting constructive criticism
The swollen pride of victory lasted only until defeat

definitions: bound by or having taken a formal oath or solemn promise
firmly determined or committed to a particular stance or position
examples: The sworn testimony was crucial to the court case
As sworn officers, they pledged to protect and serve
They were sworn enemies who refused to speak
She was his sworn ally through every challenge

definitions: relating to or consisting of syllables as units of spoken language or pronunciation
examples: The syllabic structure of haiku follows specific patterns
Japanese uses syllabic writing systems like hiragana

definitions: relating to or characteristic of woods or forest regions
examples: The sylvan setting provided a peaceful retreat from city life
They built their cabin in a sylvan paradise

definitions: involving interaction between two different organisms living in close physical association typically to mutual advantage
examples: The symbiotic relationship between bees and flowers benefits both
Their symbiotic business partnership lasted for decades

definitions: serving as a symbol or representation of something else especially something abstract
examples: The dove is symbolic of peace in many cultures
Her symbolic gesture meant more than any words

definitions: having parts that match exactly when divided by a line or point
examples: The symmetric design of the building pleased the architect
A symmetric face is often considered more attractive

definitions: made up of exactly similar parts facing each other or around an axis showing balance
examples: The symmetrical pattern of the wallpaper created visual harmony
Her symmetrical features were considered classically beautiful

definitions: feeling, showing, or expressing sympathy and concern for someone's suffering or misfortune
relating to or denoting the part of the nervous system that speeds up body functions
examples: The sympathetic teacher helped the struggling student after class
She was sympathetic to his difficult family situation
The sympathetic nervous system triggers the fight-or-flight response
Sympathetic stimulation increases heart rate during stress

definitions: relating to or having the form or character of a symphony or symphony orchestra
examples: The symphonic performance filled the concert hall with music
He composed several symphonic works during his career

definitions: showing symptoms of a particular disease or medical condition
serving as a symptom or sign indicating the existence of something else
examples: The symptomatic patients were isolated to prevent spread
Her symptomatic response to allergens required immediate treatment
Rising crime rates are symptomatic of deeper social problems
His behavior was symptomatic of underlying stress

definitions: relating to or involving synapses between nerve cells in the nervous system
examples: Synaptic transmission is crucial for brain function
The synaptic connections strengthen with repeated use

definitions: occurring or operating at the same time or rate in coordinated fashion
examples: The synchronised swimmers performed their routine flawlessly
Their synchronised watches ensured perfect timing

definitions: caused to occur or operate at the same time or rate
examples: The synchronized traffic lights improved traffic flow downtown
Their synchronized movements showed hours of practice

definitions: existing or occurring at the same time in perfect correspondence
examples: Synchronous learning requires all students to be online together
The synchronous motors operated at exactly the same speed

definitions: having a rhythm that emphasizes normally weak beats creating an off-beat effect
examples: The syncopated jazz rhythm got everyone dancing
She played syncopated melodies on the piano

definitions: relating to the interaction of elements that produce a combined effect greater than individual parts
examples: The synergistic effect of the medications improved patient outcomes
Their synergistic partnership produced innovative solutions

definitions: having the same or nearly the same meaning as another word
so closely associated as to be nearly equivalent or interchangeable
examples: Happy and joyful are synonymous adjectives
The synonymous terms confused students learning English
His name became synonymous with excellence in journalism
Quality is synonymous with their brand reputation

definitions: made by chemical synthesis rather than occurring naturally especially to imitate natural product
relating to or using synthesis combining separate elements into a coherent whole
examples: Synthetic fabrics are often more durable than natural ones
The synthetic rubber performed better in extreme temperatures
Her synthetic approach combined multiple theoretical frameworks
The report provided a synthetic overview of findings

definitions: done or acting according to a fixed plan or system showing methodical procedure
examples: The systematic review examined all available research studies
She took a systematic approach to solving complex problems

definitions: relating to or affecting an entire system rather than just individual parts
examples: The systemic problems required comprehensive reform measures
Systemic racism affects multiple aspects of society

definitions: having a striped or brindled coat pattern typically with darker markings
examples: The tabby cat had distinctive stripes on its fur
She adopted a gray tabby kitten from the shelter

definitions: prohibited or restricted by social custom making it unacceptable to do or discuss
examples: Discussing salaries was taboo in their corporate culture
Many taboo subjects are now openly discussed

definitions: arranged in or consisting of a table format with rows and columns
examples: The tabular data made comparisons much easier to see
She presented the results in tabular form

definitions: understood or implied without being stated directly or put into words
examples: Their tacit agreement needed no formal contract
She gave tacit approval with a subtle nod

definitions: reserved or uncommunicative in speech saying little and appearing stern
examples: The taciturn farmer answered questions with single words
His taciturn nature made social gatherings uncomfortable

definitions: slightly sticky to the touch not completely dry or hardened
showing poor taste or quality considered cheap or vulgar
examples: The tacky paint needed more time to dry completely
The tacky glue held the pieces together temporarily
The tacky decorations clashed with the elegant venue
His tacky jokes embarrassed everyone at dinner

definitions: relating to or constituting actions carefully planned to achieve a specific end
examples: The tactical decision to delay proved strategically wise
Police used tactical gear during the operation

definitions: connected with the sense of touch or perceptible by touch
examples: Children learn through tactile experiences with different textures
The tactile feedback helped blind users navigate

definitions: marked or labeled with a tag for identification or classification
electronically marked or identified in digital systems or social media
examples: The tagged items were ready for inventory
All tagged clothing showed clearance prices
She was tagged in several photos from the event
The tagged files were easy to search

definitions: having a tail of a specified kind or number
examples: The long-tailed bird perched on the fence
A white-tailed deer ran through the forest

definitions: having no tail either naturally or through removal
examples: The tailless cat was born without a tail
Tailless aircraft designs improve aerodynamic efficiency

definitions: made, altered, or fitted to particular measurements for a perfect fit
adapted or made for a particular purpose or person with specific needs
examples: His tailored suit fit perfectly for the wedding
The tailored jacket emphasized her professional appearance
The tailored training program met each employee's needs
They offered tailored solutions for small businesses

definitions: contaminated or polluted with something undesirable that spoils purity or quality
affected by or associated with something bad morally corrupted or damaged
examples: The tainted water supply caused widespread illness
They recalled all tainted products from store shelves
His tainted reputation made finding work difficult
The tainted evidence was thrown out of court

definitions: already occupied, in use, or claimed by someone else
strongly attracted to or charmed by someone or something
examples: This seat is taken by another passenger
All the good ideas were already taken
She was quite taken with the charming stranger
He was taken by her intelligence and wit

definitions: relating to food prepared in a restaurant for eating elsewhere
examples: They ordered takeout Chinese food for dinner
The takeout menu offered many vegetarian options

definitions: attractive, appealing, or charming in a way that captures interest
examples: Her taking smile won everyone's affection immediately
The puppy had such a taking personality

definitions: fond of or given to talking a great deal in conversation
examples: The talkative child never ran out of stories
She became more talkative after a few drinks

definitions: not dangerous or frightened of people domesticated and gentle
lacking spirit, adventure, or excitement considered dull or insipid
examples: The tame rabbits let children pet them gently
Years of training made the tiger relatively tame
The movie's tame ending disappointed action fans
His tame response surprised those expecting anger

definitions: brought from a wild state into domestication made gentle or manageable
examples: The tamed horses were safe for riding lessons
His tamed enthusiasm was more appropriate for work
